column3: Enhancing Company Communication: The Case of a Social Media Platform
column9: Alina Krischkowsky, Astrid Weiss, Sebastian Osswald, Manfred Tscheligi
column58: University of Salzburg - ICT&S, Salzburg, Salzburg
column140: Computer-Mediated Communication; Office and Workplace; User Studies
column141: This case study reports about the pilot phase of a social media platform, based on Microsoft SharePoint 2010, which should enhance the communication between and within departments of an internationally operating semiconductor manufacturing company, which has different sites in Europe, Asia and the US. Our research group monitored this pilot phase in order to increase the acceptability and usage among the employees of the company. Five different HCI actions have been undertaken for that: Information kick-off workshops to raise awareness, a survey on success criteria, an expert evaluation on usability problems, a collaborative use case definition, and a survey on benchmarking the tool in terms of user experience and acceptability. We demonstrate the benefits of HCI research for the introduction of this communication tool in the company and reflect on the advantages and disadvantages of the five actions.

column141: LibEGov.org is a web site being designed to assist public librarians in acting as an information mediator between e-government services and patrons. To help effectively meet the needs of multiple different user populations, the LibEGov portal underwent extensive usability testing with diverse users at a variety of library locations. \  \ When using the HCI best practice of conducting expert interface reviews and pilot studies prior to usability testing, we discovered minor interface problems that would have impacted the site usability and accessibility. By using iterative development with usability testing (with diverse users), we were able to achieve faster results toward the overall usability of the information architecture. We also learned that working with a third-party developer can significantly slow the process of achieving full accessibility.  \  \ Often the user testing immediately impacted the site through a series of changes. As the user testing improved the site, the time performance for the usability testing tasks improved. The resulting interface made information easier to find in a shorter amount of time, which is significant for library staff.

column141: In a house with photovoltaics, and even more in the case of an energy+ house, the awareness for the electricity flow is an important part to optimal usage of solar energy. \ An energy+ house, such as those competing in the Solar Decathlon Europe 2012, is designed to produce more energy than it consumes over the course of the year.  \ As storing electricity is complicated and inefficient, it is best to use the available solar energy as much as possible when available. \ We defined the abstract unit of "points" to simplify the overview of power production and consumption. \ We then designed a series of views based on this unit and compared them to visualizations based on the physical units of W and Wh. \ Our evaluation with 22 participants shows that points are easy to understand and appreciated by users. \ For a deeper analysis however, it is important to provide evidence and show the influencing factors of personal power consumption to generate actionable knowledge.

column141: One of the primary goals of teaching is to prepare learners for life in the real world. Given that we live in a three dimensional world educators must teach 3D concepts. As 3D content becomes increasingly available through the Internet, large display touch interaction and tangible manipulation interfaces have the potential to remove many of the user-interface barriers to widespread adoption. \  \ This case study explains the agile iterative process used to create a commercial product for education. It reveals new interactions designed to support the use of 3D content within classrooms such as occlusion minimizing 3D rotation, scale, our bubble cursor dwell selection using a mixed reality cube, and the magic hat reveal. We describe 36 weeks of hardware and software prototypes prior to the final design evaluated by hundreds of experts in educational pedagogy over the course of 2 years. Finally, we detail some of the challenges we observed at several school visits as part of a technical trial deployment. \

column3: Multi-modal Location-Aware System  for Paratrooper Team Coordination
column9: Danielle Cummings, Manoj Prasad, George Lucchese, Christopher Aikens, Tracy Hammond
column140: User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Ethnography; User Interface Design; Multi-modal interfaces
column141: Navigation and assembly are critical tasks for Soldiers in battlefield situations. Paratroopers, in particular, must be able to parachute into a battlefield and locate and assemble their equipment as quickly and quietly as possible. Current assembly methods rely on bulky and antiquated equipment that inhibit the speed and effectiveness of such operations. To address this we have created a multi-modal mobile navigation system that uses ruggedized to mark assembly points and smartphones to assist in navigating to these points while minimizing cognitive load and maximizing situational awareness. To achieve this task, we implemented a novel beacon receiver protocol that allows an infinite number of receivers to listen to the encrypted beaconing message using only ad-hoc Wi-Fi technologies.  The system was evaluated by U.S. Army Paratroopers and proved quick to learn and efficient at moving Soldiers to navigation waypoints. Beyond military operations, this system could be applied to any task that requires the assembly and coordination of many individuals or teams, such as emergency evacuations, fighting wildfires or locating airdropped humanitarian aid.

column3: Unexpected Images from the Inside: Notes from an Eastern-European Medical Workspace
column9: Paweł Woźniak, Andrzej Romanowski
column140: Health Care; Process Improvement; User Studies
column141: Understanding the peculiarities of a sophisticated goal-oriented medical workspace is a complex task. The main contribution of this user study and subsequent deployment conducted in the DDPBD (Lodz, Poland) is (a) identifying key differences between post-communist healthcare practice and Western environments in terms of technology and (b) determining the unexpected issues that appear when involving eastern-european physicians in a participatory design process. \  \ We have managed to identify the key obstacles on the road to seamless medical data sharing infrastructure. These include the physical separation of the institutions and separated governance of the hospitals as well as several human-related reasons. We have determined that habits contrary to good IT practice are in place and that medical personnel is willing to improve provided their basic IT needs are fulfilled in a manner they imagine. \ We believe that the human factor was more difficult to overcome than the infrastructural difficulties. The system presented here illustrates that performance and efficiency can be improved in some cases without redesigning the entire infrastructure. We notice that the design process must consider social relationships in doctor teams and the hierarchical structure of the institution. Furthermore, we indicate the often conflicting intereststhat are common in eastern-european medical practice and severly impact developing interactive systems for physicians. \  \ Most importantly, we have noticed that the way the DDPBD operates is highly different from Western hospitals and the acceptance of technology is highly determined by the attitude of the division heads and relationships between department members. The physicians have been involved in the design process as much as their limited time allowed for. Not only the organisation of the ward, but also the habits and preconceptions of the physicians are different and must be accommodated in different ways. In order to achieve full success and enable building more complex computational systems for this specific hospital environment even more studies of the doctors' attitudes toward technologies must be conducted.

column141: Every company starts with a handful of dreamers – those who had an “a-ha” moment and are willing to test their theory in hopes of greater achievements. Their adventure will prove successful if they are able to execute on serving than unmet need or solution that is better than what is available on the market. As the company matures, the key to growth slowly shifts away from proving their hunch, to efficient execution in order to serve the lines of customers. \  \ This focus on efficiency leads companies to hire the best talent and provide them a workspace that minimizes latency between similarly skilled team members.  However, this environment is not ideally suited for what drives innovation in user centered design, cross pollination of ideas and experiences. \  \ Qualcomm, which employs more than 23,000 employees worldwide, wanted to see if it could have the best of both worlds:  an efficient organizational structure tuned for optimal execution, combined with a more organically created second layer, where network connections are made to foster ideation and discovery of the next-next thing across all teams. \  \ Babak Forutanpour, head of Qualcomm’s Forward Looking User Experience (FLUX) program, will share his experiences and key lessons learned in building an organic, cross-discipline engine of innovation. The program is completely run by volunteer employees who have organized and capture over 45 patents-pending, and numerous prototypes. In our presentation, we discuss the “12 Ses” which have served the company well, which others may wish to apply to their UX mining programs.  \

column3: Leverage User Experience through Social Networking to Improve Health Adherence
column9: Xinxin Zhu
column140: Social Computing and Social Navigation; Input and Interaction Technologies; Virtual Community / Community Computing; Office and Workplace; Service Design
column141: Patient adherence is an important factor in improving health outcomes. However, as one of the causes of increasing population with chronic diseases, low adherence has become a major healthcare issue globally. Often, due to deferred benefits of treatment or lifestyle recommendations, many fail to adhere to their treatment regimen or health plans given by care providers until their conditions deteriorate. As poor adherence remains a significant yet inadequately addressed problem of severe health issues, it is critical to create effective interventions as part of the solutions. Previous studies have suggested that peer supports be effective to improve adherence, and social cognitive theories have indicated that personal realization and confidence enhanced through entertaining gaming elements could encourage behavior change. To understand how different motivation factors affect user experience through social networking, a healthcare adherence website with built-in behavior analyses was constructed to conduct experiments. Users' health adherence levels can be reported to the website and shared among consenting social members for discussion or competition. Key design and development components are illustrated through the case study, including a social gaming and learning portal, an engineering approach to supporting different application scenarios, and information interventions based on predefined rules to achieve effective adherence. The preliminary analysis showed that people using social media for healthcare adherence may be motivated differently and act strategically during their social interactions. \

column3: Card Sorting for Complex Software: What Happens When Best Practices Don't Work?
column9: Jennifer Shirey
column140: Information Architecture; User and Cognitive models; User Studies; User Interface Design
column141: Card sorting is a common research method often used to generate and improve the information architecture of a website. This method is associated with certain best practices—for example, researchers usually ask participants to think aloud during the sort.  \  \ This case study presents our experience with card sorting, which we used to generate ideas for improving a complex software product. During our first few studies, we were surprised to find that some recommended best practices had a negative effect on our participants. For example, thinking aloud was uncomfortable and distracting for our users. For this reason, we simplified our card sort and gave participants time to complete the sort in silence. This presentation covers this and other challenges we faced and our recommendations for using card sorting as a method for improving complex software.

The advantages of this app is that it lowers the barrier to usability testing which most people view as a expensive and time consuming process. With this app a person with minimal experience can quickly CREATE a test script and CONDUCT one or multiple usability tests. Instead of writing lengthy notes and wringing your hands at the thought of compiling the data later, the app gives simple multiple check box options for you to click and auto compiles them with success and fail rates thus providing instant results.  \  \ With this app we were able to reduce initial set up time drastically. This app does not need any paper & is a highly sustainable option. We were able to conduct Usability Validation in 30min thereby reducing participation fatigue. We were able to collect feedback at frequent intervals & at various stages of product development. column3: Automotive HMI Test Package: An Exploitable Approach to Study In-Car HMIs
column9: David Wilfinger, Alexander Meschtscherjakov, Nicole Perterer, Arno Laminger, Manfred Tscheligi
column140: Usability Testing and Evaluation; User Studies; Transport
column141: Automotive HMIs undergo an ongoing expansion of functionality, nowadays including navigation, entertainment and communication features. The quality of these interfaces in terms of usability and user experience is critical since  distraction and other negative causes of the system usage can have fatal effects. But even the best designed system causes distraction and has improvement potential. Therefore it is necessary to inform drivers of the risk that is involved in the usage of automotive HMIs. This case study therefore shows how we addressed this issue by evaluating these interfaces to inform a range of stakeholders about their qualities. These stakeholders include the automotive companies themselves, as well as journalists and motor clubs, that transport the message to the end users and politicians.  \  \ This case study describes the development of a method package for holistically evaluating in-car HMIs. The goal is to provide a toolbox that is easy to replicate and allows evaluators to identify the effects of the system usage on the driver as well as interface flaws that cause them. We applied the toolbox in two example studies, which informed the further application of the HMI study approach. We learned that the combination of established expert and end user methods in combination with a real test track lead to useful results that are easy to communicate to both scientific and public audiences.

To work towards project success, we have used a variety of participatory design strategies including: interviews, participatory design events, surveys of user needs and regular testing and feedback sessions. Testing and the participatory design process are ongoing. In this presentation, we will show our work to date and describe our lessons learned from these early experiences.

column3: Empowering Pupils to Save Energy at the School: the SESAME-S Project
column9: Peter Fröhlich, Ulrich Lehner, Peter Riedl, Anna Fensel, René Mayrhofer
column40: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
column66: University of Applied Sciences Upper Austria
column140: Context-Aware Computing; Handheld Devices and Mobile Computing; Ubiquitous Computing / Smart Environments; Visualization; Children; E-Learning and Education; Design Methods (Design Rationale, Claims Analysis, Scenarios, Storyboards); Empirical Methods, Quantitative; Empirical Methods, Qualitative; Participatory Design / Cooperative Design; Prototyping; Design Planning; User Studies; User-Centered Design / Human-Centered Design; Visual System Design / Visual Design; Usability Research; User Experience Design / Experience Design; User Interface Design; Multimedia UIs; Sustainability
column141: This case study presents the user research process of the SESAME-S project, which developed technology solutions for empowering pupils to save energy in their school buildings. While energy efficiency is a topic of high societal relevance and large investments, HCI research and development projects so far mostly been focused on private homes, but rarely on potentially more promising large building contexts. If viable solutions could be found in case studies, larger roll-outs could be expected to have significant impact both on energy awareness promoted by pupils, as well as on actual energy consumptions  \  \ In order to evaluate the requirements and necessary implementations for energy saving, the project set up a trial testbed at a secondary school in Kirchdorf, Austria. Our initial requirements research was based on workshops with project classes, contextual interviews with janitors, as well as with teachers. We found that energy saving technology in schools must especially include the consideration of organizational and social aspects, and that responsibility of stakeholders for system operation need to be clearly defined beforehand. We also gained evidence together with the pupils that power management would be most efficient when enabling people to remotely switch off computers that are not in use.  \  \ Based on a broad online questionnaire study at the school with 390 respondents, we found that pupils could be strong contributors to consumption reduction, if they were provided with the necessary empowerment. This motivated us to move on with first designs of a power management system, which we evaluated by comparing various forms of information density in three different school contexts (lecture, discussion, break). Based on the gathered learnings, we decided to discard low-density / low-interactivity displays for the final service prototype.  \  \ We finally ran a 17-week long field trial, in which we first measured energy consumption under standard conditions and then with the operation of our functional power management service. One class was provided with a tablet hanging at a central place in the classroom and to another class we provided six smartphones that could be used by individual pupils. We found that the power management service indeed had a significant energy reduction effect, but there was no significant difference in the energy savings with regard to whether a tablet or smartphones were used. We can therefore recommend the integration of power management systems within a larger number of schools, but only if they are thoroughly tested.   \  \ We think that applying a large variety of user research methods is crucial in order to enable generalizable design guidance in the special setting of a school. Particularly the enrichment of broad questionnaire studies with focused workshops and contextual interviews provided a good decision basis for our and hopefully also future projects. We learned within our user requirements that pupils need to be guided very thoroughly through empirical investigations, both as supporters and respondents. Furthermore, especially in a functional trial with a pre-mature prototype, high communication efforts must be planned into the project, in order to keep teachers and the school management informed about potential risks within the IT system operation.

column3: i-Theatre: Fostering Children's Storytelling and Creativity Through Technology
column9: Cristina Costa
column140: Children; Input and Interaction Technologies; E-Learning and Education; Tangible UIs
column141: Summary of the project  \  \ i-Theatre was a 2 years long project with the purpose of designing and developing a fully functional, interactive and integrated system for creating and telling stories dedicated to children (5-6 years old). At the end of the project, the team delivered a final prototype that was engineered and deployed into a product. \ The project involved a multidisciplinary team fully involved in all phases of the prototype life, that included researchers, designers, developers, educators, and product manager. \ The prototype evolved through three major cycles of design, development and evaluation. Involvement of stakeholders was a focus of the project, and evaluations were inserted into real contexts of use.  \  \ Best practices, when designing for young children: \ #1 keep it simple - a tradeoff between simplicity and functionalities is important to keep the focus on the main activities \ #2 maintain the connection with physical word – young children still need it \ #3 take into account the existing context – your system or device does not live alone, but could be inserted between a wider scholastic programme \ #4 focus on the pedagogical goals - fancy functionalities may be attractive but in the long term your system or device should offer an added value \ #5 get a multidiscipliary team that allows to consider and to give the right importance to all aspects both of the user experience and technical challenges \ #6 accurately plan evaluation moments creating an environment comfortable and enjoyable for children - organizing real context environment (e.g. a workshop for a class in school or museum) in collaboration with school teachers or educators gives real information of how the system or device will be used. \

column141: This case study presents the requirements analysis, conception, design, engineering, and development of a investigation tool for media companies. Media companies are faced with actual changes triggered by technological progress. The market pressure to work more effective, efficient and to improve the quality forces media companies to re-design their processes and take a convergent value-added process chain into account. Therefore our stakeholders came up with the idea to develop an investigation/monitoring tool to support their staff in their daily work. \  \ Concerning the processes and management of media data the basic goals were established based on the current state of research and the daily practice of our partners:  \ * Make investigation more efficient and effective \ * Optimize workflows in daily work \ * Use potentials of ongoing technologies due to market pressure and innovation \ * Monitoring of data channels and (prod)users \ * Collecting data and calculate topic relevances \  \ A new project was started to find possible improvements based on the daily user tasks of editors and writers working in the media company. At first we analyzed and documented the requirements in workshops with different stakeholders, especially the end users. Then it turned out that there are some special requirements concerning processes, search, visualization and relevance calculation for media articles which have to be revealed with domain experts.  \  \ In an iterative conception and design phase we developed ideas with creative techniques, paper prototyping and interactive prototyping. In cooperation with stakeholders we chose one of the ideas for refinement and development. In some meetings which were conducted as focus groups we even revealed further requirements. \  \ In the subsequent development phase we followed an agile approach and integrated important stakeholders in the development process. Frequent reviews led us to the actual working system called MMVisT. At the current state of the project we got more funds to further develop MMVisT and improve design, number of data sources, relevance calculation and search techniques. \  \ Help editors and writers in media companies to overview, find and select relevant information for new topics and thus simplify the creation of new articles. React on the participation of (prod)users in convergent workflows. \  \ With our holistic usability engineering approach we came to some interesting findings and best practices we learned: \ * a combination of methods and an iterative holistic approach helped us to analyze the requirements \ * by integrating the stakeholders into the development process we could make important decisions concerning technology, concepts, processes, search, visualization, interaction and design  \ * search and visualization techniques are needed to manage the large amount of data \ * processes in media companies have to be adapted based on (prod)users and media convergence \ * relevance for articles and topics can calculated based on many different (web) data sources \ * it is still to prove if effectiveness, efficiency and quality can be improved by our tool

Instead of looking for material caches, players of RealityCaching (users with a mobile phone equipped with GPS and camera) can find and share with friends virtual caches with several multimedia contents (e.g. photos, videos, songs, messages) and gain points thanks to these activities. They can access these “gifts” by reaching the geographic location of the cache and positioning their phone according to the spatial coordinates of the object (for example, the cache could be placed on the top of a tree, so the user has to move the phone to capture the cache). The main contributes given by the AR on a basic geo-caching application are the impossibility to take away the cache from its place (voluntary or not) and the opportunity to dedicate a cache to a specific friend or group, while the incentive to go outdoors remains the same as the original game model. \  \ The goal of this case study is to collect data of human mobility and habits by using the Game With a Purpose (GWAP) paradigm, implemented on the RealityCaching mobile app. For example, we plan to discover the patterns of different routes chosen to reach a specific location by different users, their favorite spots to place caches according to the content of the caches, etc. Starting from these results, we will improve our RealityCaching app (e.g. with new features or interaction improvements) and also create new apps and services useful for the player (e.g. services based on users’ needs brought out by the use of the game).  \

column141: The face of software is changing: Users are moving away from employing a small number of large, "complete-solution" applications to assembling a toolbox of many small, single-purpose tools. Unfortunately, large companies like Adobe are typically set up to build large software. Creating small ($1 - $10 million in yearly revenue) products can be challenging. \  \ This case study reports on the implementation of a new development process, called "Pipeline", designed to rapidly prototype and evaluate small applications. Pipeline is designed with user research at its core. Starting ideas for new products are identified through Contextual Inquiry. Once a product direction is selected, an iterative process of development and evaluation is carried out over a 13-week period. Opportunities to pivot are built in at 3-week intervals, driven by evaluation results from laboratory studies. The Pipeline process is explained through an example product prototype, called "Gadget". Gadget is an application targeted at Web developers that helps them more easily experiment and modify the visual layout of a Web page. \  \ The principal challenge in implementing the Pipeline process was in obtaining upper management buy-in. This case study will also report on the tactics used to sell the process in our organization. In particular, the most successful tactic was offering arguments for why Pipeline would avoid pitfalls that caused us to build unsuccessful products in the past.

column141: Our case study illustrates ways to maximize the educational potential of an idle moment in the customers' restaurant experience–waiting for their meals. We developed a hybrid game using both table-top as well as SMS interactions to engage families in discussions about health. Our research investigates the following; (1) how games can influence an individuals understanding of their health and lifestyle behaviors, (2) how individuals share knowledge through the hybridization of services, table-top and SMS games, and health messaging, (3) how structural, environmental and social factors within restaurant settings enable individuals to start conversations and share ideas about healthy eating. \  \ In August 2011, the Fitwits program (www.fitwits.org) was approached by Eat’n Park, a regional restaurant chain to create a five-week promotional game to help families start conversations about nutrition and correct portion sizes while enjoying their meal. The partnership provided an opportunity for cross-sector collaboration, implementing Fitwits into 73 Eat’n Park Restaurants across Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia, with the potential to reach 85,000 families during the promotional period. To accomplish this, we needed to work with academic, nonprofit and private companies in addition to the IRB review board to develop this program implemented in a public restaurant chain. \  \ During the Fitwits promotion there was a 5.8% year-over-year increase in sales of healthy meal options sold off the kids menu. A high number of collector cards and games were requested by families which is an indication that interest and engagement in the game was high. Families that played the integrated SMS game showed very good engagement in the game, with 74% rate of completing the game for those that started to play. In addition, many families went on to explore other aspects of the SMS interaction including checking recipes and providing feedback about their experience. The engagement of the family in discussion about health was reflected in both user feedback as well as reports by restaurant staff.  \  \ The results collected from the SMS game illustrate that table-top games in combination with the SMS messaging system was impactful helped facilitate conversations about health. As indicated on the post-survey from the Eat’n Park employees, much work is needed to better train staff on dissemination procedures if the promotion is implemented again. It was also clear from staff feedback that better marketing and more complete integration into the restaurant experience would improve recognition of the game and engagement. \  \ In summary, one of our main goals was to maximize the educational potential of an idle moment in the customers' restaurant experience–waiting for their meals, affording a method of engagement that was both fun and accessible. In this context, desirable behavior change includes: (a) increasing the ability for people to learn new skills that will help them identify and change bad habits, (b) using the dinner table as a proactive space where participants openly engage and communicate about their own families’ health. We feel we have made a first step into a very exciting area of research and look forward to using the information from our case study to create a more formalized study.

While this repetitive cycle can be frustrating for English-speaking users, for Asian language searchers the cycle is but one step in a more arduous journey to search success. They may be initially confronted by a keyboard that has no native language characters, may be required to enter characters in their native language using an Input Method Editor (IME), and may be able to enter their query in multiple character sets (e.g., for Japanese speakers, Romaji, Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji). This paper presents one program of research investigating these and similar issues in Japan. Given the multiple links in the chain from input to intent, we investigated the issues using multiple methods (task analysis, logs analysis, usability study, live testing) and produced recommendations across multiple domains (search suggestion, related search, spelling correction) as well. We believe that fellow researchers and international users alike will benefit from learning about our methods and our substantive findings.

Orlando's constraints made log files the primary viable source for conducting usability research. Usability research had to be cost-effective and have no negative impact on the website.  \  \ After requirements gathering, design, and finally development, log file reanimation through ViDLog was evaluated. 10 usability professionals viewed logfile-recorded website usage using ViDLog and were then asked to infer users’ goals, strategies, successes or failures, and proficiencies; and afterwards, rate, ViDLog across multiple dimensions.  \  \ ViDLog’s log file reanimation proved successful for gaining usability insights; usability professionals were able to infer users’ goals, strategies, successes or failures, and proficiencies. Usability professionals were able to do this without ViDLog training, without familiarity of the website being evaluated (Orlando), and without domain knowledge of the subject depicted in the user sessions (women’s literature).  \  \ This case study features a first iteration of the design and evaluation of ViDLog's log file reanimation, and as such, discovered limitations in the evaluation methodology, and inefficiencies in ViDLog's user interface. Future work should test a wider variety of log data, and use an improved version of ViDLog's user interface and feature set, based off of findings in this case study.

column141: Unlike other methodological papers, this paper is less concerned with the validity of findings, but with what’s happening to user research findings in a product development organization.  \  \ We argue that this focus has largely been amiss in the published practical HCI research literature. In fact, the method we are introducing here yielded only very few new insights. Most of what we found was known already. Yet, we still advocate the adoption of this method, because the way these ‘insights’ were gained made a big difference to how the organization acted on them - and ultimately how products changed and users benefited from the insights.  \  \ In this paper we describe a project we ran at Google for six months. We called it ‘Project Pokerface’ for reasons that will become clear further on. It involved more than 400 colleagues from engineering and product management across 7 countries running their own observational user study. This immersion exercise allowed non-UX professionals to feel firsthand the delight and pain of our users when using our products. It strengthened the bond between product-focused Googlers and 'their' users and called attention to issues that needed immediate attention. \  \ Our goals in describing this project are twofold. First, we want draw attention to the fact that user research typically is a process embedded in an organization where success is not just determined by classic scientific benchmarks (validity, reliability, or - possibly - citation count), but predominantly by the improvements made to products. We can think of it as real-world impact factors. Methodological publications in HCI, as well as the education of practitioners, in our view gloss over this need (Granka, Larvie, Riegelsberger EPIC 2008).  \  \ Second, we believe that user researchers in other product development organizations can learn from our successes and failures with Project Pokerface. We hope they will be able to further evolve and adapt this method to affect positive change in their organizations.  \  \ We are aware that the success of such approaches strongly depends on the organizational culture. The way in which priorities are set, how tasks are managed, how incentives are given to engineers and product managers will influence not only the success of such an endeavor, but also its feasibility within an organization. Google, with its culture of engineering autonomy, 20% time, and consensus-driven decision-making is probably a unique environment, yet it also showcases some of work methods that other organizations are aiming for.

column141: Comparative study between two usability evaluation methods, abstract: \ Digital products designed for children should be validated by children. When it comes to usability testing, not all the available methods which work well with adults are equally applicable with child participants. In our study, we investigated two methods, Peer Tutoring which was developed for children, and Active Intervention which originates from the more traditional Think- Aloud methodology with adults. Our goal was to find out which of the two methods does elicit more comments by 8-10 years old boys when using a web application. The results showed that Peer Tutoring did elicit the greatest number of comments. At the same time the number of prompts provided by the test moderator was tendentially lower than during Active Intervention. According to previous research we classified the comments provided by the children in three categories: in action, planning, and perception and cognition comments. This brought to light that more action and tendentially planning comments were provided during Peer Tutoring than during Active Intervention. The number of perception and cognition comments did not differ between the two methods. \  \ Best practices learned: \ - Peer Tutoring enabled us to provide a rather natural test situation to the children, and at the same time learn more about our product thus about how children perceive it. \  \ - Based on these results we concluded that Peer Tutoring can help to elicit more self-motivated responses. \  \ - We observed the same result tendencies and advantages in several Peer Tutoring studies with young children of both genders. \  \ - The study design, i.e. the methods used, are well replicable for other practitioners. \

In sum, and based on our findings, we do believe that service design, which provides a holistic view of the problems, can be used to tackle the crisis problem by leveraging synergies and unleashing opportunities. \ Don't let yourself stay still. \

column3: Breakthrough User Experience Requires UX to Own the Front-End Development Team
column9: Jim Nieters, Amit Pande, Uday Shankar, Ankit Kumar
column140: Prototyping; Development Tools / Toolkits / Programming Environments; Software architecture and engineering; Experience Strategy; Software Engineering Methods and Processes - Mathematical/Formal; User Experience Design / Experience Design; User Interface Design
column141: How can it be that so many digital products fail deliver any inspiration when so many technology and digital media companies spend millions of dollars on design and user experience? Merely following user-centered design (UCD) practices by the book is not sufficient to create truly transformative digital products. In fact, the digital product industry confronts this alarming paradox: More and more UX teams claim to follow user-centered processes, yet most digital products are mediocre or even substandard. And things won’t get easier. As interactions progress from clicks to taps and other gestures, traditional UCD processes will face even greater challenges. In our experience, one reason for poor design execution is that there is a separation between the design and development of the presentation layer. UX teams need to own more than just design. We need to own front-end development. In fact, we argue that front-end development has always been more strongly aligned with design than with development. This case study highlights how the User Experience organization within the HP Consumer Travel division at HP transformed its products by taking ownership of front-end UI development. We also highlight the benefits achieved, the political challenges, and the provide recommendations for how other practitioners can in fact move into a position where they own front-end development as well.

column3: Integrating UCD in the Context of Satellite Ground Segments Development: A View From The Trenches

column141: French space agency (CNES) conceives and executes satellite missions for various applications (civil, defense, scientific research…). Satellite ground segment is a key part for supporting a satellite mission. It encompasses people who supervise the mission and satellite platform, as well as systems used to accomplish these monitoring and control tasks. This case study focuses on the design and development of the platform and operation control system. Reliability prevails on usability during the development process but delivered ground segment applications suffer from usability issues and operators are providing negative feedback (in the last five years, there has even been one case of a xM€ ground segment application being design, built and delivered but never used). \  \ The presented case study exposes how a UCD approach has been successfully integrated to the existing CNES development process. The TORTUGA (Task, Operations, Reliability and Training for Users of Ground Applications) project has been set up to experiment a new development approach for ground segment applications. The team gathered engineers and researchers from CNES (ground segment products department, missions and operations department), as well as engineers and researchers from IRIT lab (Interactive Critical Systems team). The project first focused on a particular satellite mission in order to precisely observe and analyze operators’ activities and the tools they were using. The main steps of the project were then to integrate UCD techniques, such as task analysis, low-fidelity and high-fidelity prototyping, to the existing development process. Low-fidelity prototyping and high-fidelity prototyping phases are the core of our best practice solution. They are iterative and supported by modeling and development software tools which have been designed for this purpose. This best practice solution has been validated on a ground segment application of another mission. Head of ground segment products department agreed on the benefits of UCD and its capability to ensure usability. Since then, the proposed solution has been integrated in the new ground segment products development process imposed by CNES to its software suppliers. \

column141: Three behavioral science informed applications are designed to support users to reduce energy consumption through the use of one of three interactive user motivational frames; affective, cognitive and social. We aim to produce ambient interfaces that are engaging and scalable and use smart meter electricity data. Each of the applications incorporates behavior recommendations, behavior commitments, goal setting, energy and behavior feedback and email reminders. In addition, algorithms are developed for baselining of energy to calculate savings.  Beginning with ethnography to guide initial concept development, we integrated feedback from over 600 individuals via user tests, interface tests, and randomized controlled assessment of effects of prototypes on interface stickiness and behavioral intention. Best practices include use of research to guide interface design and interactivity, integration of most effective behavior change techniques, and the use of social media to influence behavior and for scalability.
